story.l1: It was a dark and stormy Tuesday night. (really!)
story.l2: Joanna and Gabe first crossed paths at a fundraiser in midtown Manhattan. They bonded over a shared love of music and the arts—though they disagreed strongly on whether Lang Lang is a great pianist.
story.l3: After a few evenings exchanging Spotify lists, watching films, and discovering a shared appreciation for Eataly, Broadway, and cocktail bars—they knew they had found something special in each other. In the years since, they’ve called the diverse community of Long Island City home, while continuing to explore the arts and culinary scene in New York.
story.l4: In the fall of 2019, Gabe proposed during a candlelight cruise in the Riviera Maya, Mexico. A year later, Joanna and Gabe were married in an intimate ceremony on October 10, 2020 — as much fun as that was, they can’t wait to celebrate with all of their favorite people.
story.l5: They also still disagree on Lang Lang — although they both agree Martha Argerich is better anyway.

wedding.subt: All wedding activities will be at the same location.

faq.subt:
We will be updating these regularly!
If you can’t find what you’re looking for, please reach out via
faq.q1: Is this the best way to get the latest information about the wedding?
faq.a1: Yes! We will be updating this website as the year goes on. Please check back for the most updated information.
faq.q2: What's the best way to reach you if we have questions?
faq.a2: Please reach us via the Contact Us section or email us directly at：
faq.a2-en: If you are unsure if we have your most up to date email, phone, or address, please reach out!
faq.q3: Will there be a Zoom or livestream of the wedding if I can’t make it?
faq.a3: No, we currently do not have plans to livestream the wedding.
faq.q4: What if you plan to postpone?
faq.a4:
While we don’t anticipate further postponement, we will be responsive to any circumstances that may impact the health and safety of our guests.

Any announcements about the status of the wedding will be posted on our website first. We plan to contact all guests via phone or other electronic means (email, DM, etc.) if there are urgent updates.

If you would like us to have your email or phone on file for the latest updates, please feel free to reach us via the Contact Us section or send us an email at
faq.a5:
We don’t have one in the traditional sense. Under the circumstances and hardships of the past year, your presence at our event is more than enough. We are truly blessed and are just happy to be celebrating if you are able to join us. 

That said, we have a feeling that this won’t stop the very generous among you! From our honeymoon fund link below, you'll be able to directly offset some of the costs from our upcoming getaway, or to otherwise put your generosity towards charitable causes we care deeply about and want to help support.
faq.a6:
For international guests planning to stay in New York City, John F. Kennedy International Airport (JFK) is likely to be your best option.

Domestic guests, especially those who are staying in New Jersey, may want to fly into Newark Liberty International Airport (EWR) instead.

 Otherwise, JFK is likely the best option for anyone staying in Manhattan or Queens.
faq.a7:
The dress code for our wedding is Black Tie (Required). It means wear a tuxedo or an evening gown (see here) and have fun with it!
Equivalent formal dress in the Taiwanese / Chinese (modern Qipao or Zhongshan suit) and Filipino tradition (Barong tagalog or Maria Clara dress) are also acceptable options.

email.l1:
Questions? Recently moved? Let us know the latest. 
If available, please upload your COVID Vaccine Record(s) below. Your information will be kept confidential and help us ensure all attending guests' well-being.
email.upload: Choose the file(s) and don't forget to click Upload to finalize the file selection!

covid.subt:
Bringing the most important people in our lives (you!) to the same location all at once presents some logistical challenges in our current environment.

We wanted to share the expectations we feel are necessary to ensure the comfort and well-being of everyone in attendance, and explain some of our thinking behind these guidelines. While we recognize that some of these precautions may be inconvenient, there are no exceptions to these guidelines for any of our vendors or guests.

We expect guests who are considered vulnerable populations in attendance: our elders, parents or caregivers in regular contact with young children, and expecting mothers. These precautions are especially important for reducing risk on their behalf.

We respect everyone’s right to make their own informed decision about vaccination, and in turn request careful compliance with precautions as outlined if you plan to attend.

Thank you in advance for your understanding. We kindly ask that you check this site regularly for updates as we get closer to November.
covid.q-1: How frequently will you update these guidelines?
covid.a-1: We expect to make updates through the summer as we track vaccination rates in New York City, as well as in cities and countries our guests are from. We will reevaluate all guidance here by September 20, 2021 (60 days prior to the wedding). We are also closely tracking news on the new delta variant, and to what extent it will impact our expectations for this fall.
covid.q-2: Will we need to bring masks?
covid.a-2: Yes. We’ll be reassessing our stance on this and other COVID-related measures as we get closer to the wedding. In general, we will be adopting mask policies that should be very similar to those in the hospitality and travel industries around the time of the wedding in November.
covid.q-3: What if I forget to bring my mask?
covid.a-3: We will have a small supply of disposable masks as a precaution. You’re highly encouraged to bring your own mask, also so that you can coordinate it with your outfit.
covid.q-4: When will I need to wear a mask?
covid.a-4: For now, masks will need to be worn anytime you are not eating or drinking, or are moving around the venue away from your chair or designated table. We recognize this impacts dancing and moving about during reception, so we’re using feedback from Spring/Summer 2021 weddings to inform our approach in the fall. Stay tuned!
covid.q-5: How is mask wearing going to be enforced?
covid.a-5: We plan to implement a three strike rule: a reminder, a warning, and then being escorted out of the venue. (So until our position on this changes, please wear a mask!)
covid.a-6:
Yes. Our venue, Weylin, has a maximum capacity which exceeds our guest count by a healthy margin. As a result, we are fortunate to have a bit more flexibility with our seating arrangements and event flow.

We’re excited to share more specifics as we get closer, which will be considered alongside our mask policy.
covid.q-7: Will COVID rapid or PCR testing before the wedding be required?
covid.a-7: Yes, for everyone has not had a complete vaccination series by our wedding date.
covid.q-8: I was fully vaccinated. Do I need to present a test?
covid.a-8:
No, but we ask that you provide us with proof of vaccination. You can upload your vaccination records via the Contact Us section. We will be collecting vaccination details on a rolling basis from guests as we get closer to the date.

If you have taken a vaccine that requires a series (Pfizer or AstraZeneca), you will need to have completed both shots. For those who have taken the Johnson & Johnson vaccine, proof of vaccination is sufficient.
covid.q-9: I have not been vaccinated or don’t plan to be. Do I need to present a test?
covid.a-9: Yes, you will need to provide a negative PCR or rapid test.
covid.q-10: What kind of COVID tests will be required?
covid.a-10:
For non-vaccinated guests, we will require either of the following at the door prior to entering the venue.

1. A negative PCR test. Results must be returned within 72 hours of our wedding start time. Test results from before 5pm EST on November 17th will not be valid.

2. A negative rapid test. Results must be returned within 6 hours of our wedding start time. Test results from before 11am EST on November 20th will not be valid.
covid.q-11: What if I take a PCR test prior to the wedding and it comes back too early? What if it doesn’t come in time at all?
covid.a-11:
As a precaution, we are working on fall-back options for rapid testing.

We expect COVID testing will become cheaper and more accessible by later this year. If so, we hope to make those options available to our guests if the economics allow. That said, we believe full vaccination will be the best and safest way to enjoy our wedding, and highly encourage it even outside of our event.
covid.q-12: What if I took a test and it came back negative, but I am feeling sick or unwell?
covid.a-12: As a precaution, we kindly ask that you stay home—both for your own health and for those at the event.
covid.q-13: Will you be doing contact tracing?
covid.a-13: Yes. More information to come here as the event comes closer.
covid.a-14:
Our vendors have all been thoughtful and gracious partners in planning to make our event safe and successful. At a minimum, they are committed to the same expectations as guests as outlined here.

For vendors who are handling food or who we expect will be interacting with guests, heighted precautions and preventative measures that have been proposed and which we plan to take, pending their success in the upcoming spring wedding season in the United States and New York City metro areas in particular.

We expect to learn a lot between now and our wedding, and will share more specific details as we finalize decisions.
